<p></p><p>Monad is a structure with type constructor <i>M</i> and two functions <i>unit </i>(<span style="font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; language: en-US; mso-ascii-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;;">?)</span> and <i>multiplication </i>(<span style="font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; language: en-US; mso-ascii-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;;">µ).</span></p><p><span style="font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; language: en-US; mso-ascii-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;;"></span></p><p><span style="font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; language: en-US; mso-ascii-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;;"><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></span> <br /></p><p>and</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," />&nbsp; </p><p>To lift value from <i>a</i> to <i>Ma</i> we need <i>unit </i>function and to flatten from <i>M(Ma)</i> to <i>Ma</i> we need <i>multiplication</i>. <br /></p><p>Why do we need monad in functional programming? Why do we need functional programming anyways?</p><p>Functional programming is a paradigm which uses pure functions to build an application. The power of pure functions are, we can compose them and we can build complex things out of the small and simple functions. </p><p>If we have these functions</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," />&nbsp;</p><p>and</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," />&nbsp;</p><p>We can get</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," />&nbsp;</p><p>We can use below general purpose compose function to compose any two pure functions.<br /></p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," />&nbsp;</p><p>If we need to compose three functions then we can do like</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>Now, we can't build application using only pure functions. It is next to impossible. We need side effects anyways to make the application practical in use. To achieve the goal, we need to keep pure functions in center/core part of application and need to move side effects outside of core layer as much as possible.</p><p><img alt="" height="266" src="data:image/png;base64," width="270" /></p><p>How can we achieve this?</p><p>Side effects may occur at any part of application. (e. g. console log, taking input from user, writing/reading files, sending/receiving data to/from network, handling future value (asynchronous scenario), handling errors etc.)</p><p>As pure function returns same exact value for&nbsp; particular input values always, pure function can't stay pure if it tries to handle any of the above scenario.<br /></p><p>Suppose, we have a function below, it throws error if value is zero. <br /></p><p><img alt="" height="156" src="data:image/png;base64," width="304" /><br /></p><p>This is not a pure function as it has side effect. How can we make it 
pure and can delay or wrap the side effect and move it to outer layer of 
application?</p><p><img alt="" height="155" src="data:image/png;base64," width="427" /></p><p>We have used <i>Either </i>here. <i>Either </i>is a monad. We wrapped success and failure both case in same monad. So, our function will always return the <i>Either </i>in both of the scenario. It became pure now.&nbsp;</p><p>If we do not use <i>Either </i>we need to handle error right away or need to throw error again which does not make any function pure and increases code complexity too.</p><p><img alt="" height="176" src="data:image/png;base64," width="366" /> <br /></p><p>If we use <i>Either </i>we can handle the error later.&nbsp;</p><p><img alt="" height="154" src="data:image/png;base64," width="484" /></p><p>This way we are moving side effects to outer layer as much as possible and&nbsp; trying to make function pure in core code.</p><p>Did you notice <i>map </i>function in code? Functor has map function, and monad is a functor too, so lets take a brief introduction of functor.</p><p>Functor lifts values and functions between those values.<br /></p><p>If we have function</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>then functor <i>F</i> lifts <i>a</i> to <i>Fa</i>, <i>b</i> to <i>Fb </i>and <i>f</i> to <i>Ff</i>. This way, we have another function like,</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>To get the new function <i>Ff </i>we can reuse original function <i>f</i>, the <i>Ff </i>can be called <i>map</i> too.<br /></p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," />&nbsp; </p><p>Functor has limitation. It just lifts values and functions, it can't unlift or flatten it. That is where monad comes into picture. How can we convert <i>Mb</i> to <i>b</i>, and make the functions composable.</p><p>We need to define an extra function to make this whole expression looks like compose.</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>The extra function is</p><p></p><p></p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>Notice that this is <i>multiplication </i>or <span style="font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; language: en-US; mso-ascii-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;;">µ (can be called <i>flatten </i>or <i>join </i>too).</span></p><p></p><p></p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>So, including the above function in normal compose, we can make functions returning monadic value composable.</p><p>There is another&nbsp; function we need to pay some attentions to it is..</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>This is not the same as&nbsp;</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /> <br /></p><p>But, as monad is a functor too.&nbsp; We can find the map for above scenario as..</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>So, new compose will become like..</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /> <br /></p><p>To make composition work we introduce two functions <i>map </i>and <i>flatten </i>here. As composition always evaluates in revers order, we can call combined function of these both as <i>flatMap</i>. If you ever worked with monad you can recall <i>flatMap</i>.<br /></p><p>Now, we can create pure functions hiding / delaying side effects and we can compose that functions as well. <br /></p><p>We have type constructor M, so it is good to define a function which can accept value, lifts it (using type constructor) and returns monadic value.</p><p><img alt="" src="data:image/png;base64," /></p><p>This is called <i>unit</i> or <span style="font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; language: en-US; mso-ascii-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Cambria Math&quot;;">? (can be called <i>return </i>too).</span></p><p>If we describe monad very simply than..&nbsp;</p><p>Monad is a container / context / structure for value with type constructor <i>M</i>, and functions <i>unit </i>and <i>multiplication</i>.</p><p>This is very basic and summarized&nbsp; article of monad.<br /></p><p>We will see complex and in-depth understanding of monad using category theory in next article.<br /></p>
